College of Chemical and Bioengineering, Guilin University of Technology Guilin 541006 China As the crucial role of zeolite catalysts becomes increasingly prominent in refining and petrochemical industries, this study introduces a novel application of xMn / HY catalysts in ethane catalytic dehydrogenation via Chemical Looping Oxidative Dehydrogenation (CL-ODH). The synergistic effect of manganese oxides on the HY framework and a moderate amount of acidic sites within the catalyst facilitates the cleavage of C-H bonds and the desorption of olefins, which are vital for advancing ethane CL-ODH. We identified the reasons for maintaining high ethylene selectivity using advanced characterization techniques such as XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR. Notably, under optimized conditions at 700 °C with a gas time-space velocity (GHSV) of 1800 mL·h−1·g−1, the 3Mn/HY catalyst achieved approximately 97.1 % selectivity for ethylene and a 22.7 % conversion of ethane. These findings present a scalable route for ethylene production, showcasing significant industrial relevance by potentially reducing energy costs and improving yield. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mn-based catalyst Zeolite Ethane oxidative dehydrogenation Ethylene selectivity Lewis acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene is one of the most pivotal foundations within the global petrochemical sector, extensively applied across vital commercial chemical products, including styrene, vinyl acetate, ethylene oxide, linear alpha olefins, and polymers [1]. In recent years, driven by the burgeoning demand from the packaging, fiber, and plastic industries for polyethylene and ethylene glycol, there has been a sharp increase in the global market for ethylene. Against this backdrop, it becomes imperative for China, the world’s second-largest ethylene producer following the United States, to develop novel, green, efficient, and sustainable production technologies to meet the growing demands of the olefin market. Traditional ethylene production heavily relies on energy-intensive and high-emission steam cracking processes, utilizing ethane, naphtha, and liquefied petroleum gas as feedstocks [2]. In light of the high energy consumption, significant emissions, and relatively low selectivity for specific olefins associated with these methods, the industry has explored the extraction of ethane from natural gas or shale gas, employing selective oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethane to produce ethylene [3]. The ODH of ethane involves mixing ethane with oxidants such as O2, CO2, or N2O and conducting ethane dehydrogenation under oxidative conditions, thereby reducing the reaction temperature to below 550 °C without necessitating substantial energy input [4]. However, this approach still faces several practical challenges, including the combustibility of the gas mixture and the uncontrollability of exothermic reactions in the O2-ODH process, potentially leading to explosive hazards, and the costly and energy-intensive oxygen production required by air separation units (ASU) [5]; compared to O2-ODH, CO2-ODH is safer and more material-efficient, yet the need for carbon dioxide capture and concentration increases the costs [6]. Chemical looping oxidative dehydrogenation (CL-ODH) emerges as an innovative method for ethylene production, leveraging lattice oxygen from metal oxide carriers to facilitate ethane conversion. This approach circumvents the thermodynamic equilibrium limitations of thermal cracking and avoids the direct mixing of molecular oxygen with alkanes seen in traditional ODH processes [7]. In CL-ODH, ethane is converted into ethylene and water through the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [8], simultaneously replenishing the catalyst's oxygen vacancies with O2 (or CO2), thus reoxidizing the metal oxide to its initial state for cycle completion [9]. As a transition metal, manganese oxides are attractive for their excellent catalytic properties, stability, and variable chemical valence. In the past few years, the application of Mn-based in CL-ODH has been extensively studied by Li et al. [10–13]. Redox catalysts doped with alkali additives for Mn/SiO2 and Mn/MgO may produce good redox stability, oxygen-carrying capacity, high ethane conversion, and ethylene selectivity. Furthermore, three manganese-containing mixed oxides—Mg6MnO8, SrMnO3, and CaMnO3—that are promoted by 20 wt% Na2WO4 may demonstrate varying capacities for selective hydrogen combustion (SHC) at temperatures between 550 and 850 ℃. Moreover, promoting Mg6MnO8 with Na2WO4 may improve the selectivity of hydrogen combustion while inhibiting the activation of ethylene produced by feedstock ethane or metal oxides. High oxygen capacity core-shell Na2WO4/CuMnO2 oxygen carriers were applied in CL-ODH by Wang et al. [7]. Their results demonstrated an adequate oxygen capacity of 4.8 wt% at 720 °C, an H2 conversion of greater than 90 %, an ethane conversion of 58.8 %, and an ethylene selectivity of 86.4 %. In addition, based on the variation in adequate oxygen capacity, the conversion of CuMn2O4 to Cu, MnO, Mn3O4, and CuMnO2 during the CL-ODH process was examined. See Table S1 for more details on the research findings. Since the 21st century, zeolites have been widely applied in ion exchange, adsorption separation, and catalysis thanks to their excellent properties, such as particular microporous structure, relatively specific surface area, abundant acidic centers, and exchangeable cations [14]. Heondo Jeong et al. [15] looked into the impact of methane carbon dioxide reforming on the syngas reaction over Ni/HY catalysts. Liu et al. [16] prepared Mn/USY zeolite catalysts with different Mn contents using the isovolumetric impregnation method and explored the performance of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) denitrification under low-temperature conditions (<200 °C). Xing et al. [17] investigated the mechanism and kinetics of the cracking and oxidation of waste polypropylene over Mn2O3/HY catalysts using TG-MS and in situ FTIR techniques. Xiang [18] studied the performance of Cu/HY catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction and its deactivation reason in a fixed-bed reactor. The combination of metal oxides and zeolites in ethane oxidative dehydrogenation reactions has gradually increased in the past few decades. Wang et al. [19–21] recently used the unique three-dimensional structure and acidic sites of HY zeolite to shear the dual active sites and isolate dehydrogenation and oxidation. This prevented the deep oxidation of ethylene and produced an 18 % C2H6 conversion and nearly 100 % C2H4 selectivity for ODHE at 600 °C. In this study, xMn / HY catalysts with HY-type zeolite as carriers were prepared, tested, and characterized as redox catalysts for ethane CL-ODH, aiming to investigate the feasibility of the xMn / HY catalysts and to provide new perspectives and directions for developing redox catalysts of CL-ODH of ethane with high selectivity and reactivity. 2 Experiment 2.1 Chemicals Manganese(Ⅱ) nitrate hexahydrate (Mn(NO3)2·6 H2O, 98 %) purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. HY zeolite (n(SiO2)/n(Al2O3)=5.4) and Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite were supplied by the Catalyst Plant of Nankai University. Air (21 % oxygen/balanced nitrogen), reaction gas (10 % ethane/90 % nitrogen), and argon (purity ≥99.99 %) are supplied by Liuzhou Huaao Gas Co. 2.2 Preparation of redox catalysts The synthesis of xMn / HY catalysts, with "x" representing the theoretical mass fraction of Mn2O3, was conducted via the isovolumetric impregnation method to achieve varying Mn loadings. Initially, a predetermined quantity of HY zeolite was placed into a beaker. Subsequently, dropwise aqueous Mn(NO3)2·6 H2O at various concentrations was gradually added to ensure thorough saturation and uniform dispersion of the zeolite with the precursor solution. Following saturation, the zeolite-precursor mixture was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 hours. The dried samples were then calcinated in a muffle furnace at 800 °C for 4 hours. Post-calcination, the catalysts were finely ground, passing through a mesh size of 40–60 to ensure uniform particle size and optimal catalytic activity. 2.3 Performance of redox catalysts The assessment of catalytic reactions was conducted using an atmospheric fixed-bed reactor. 0.5 g (40–60 mesh) of catalyst was loaded into a U-shaped quartz reactor tube with an outer diameter of 8 mm, an inner diameter of 6 mm, and a length of 440 mm, and the ends were plugged with a bit of quartz cotton. The catalyst's center had a type K thermocouple to guarantee precise temperature monitoring. After that, they were loaded into a fixed-bed reactor, and the gap between the reactor shell and the U-tube was filled with quartz wool, waiting for the temperatures to rise to 675 °C, 700 °C, and 725 °C, respectively. The entire process was split into two phases: oxidation and reduction. During the oxidation step, the sample was exposed to 21 % oxygen/balanced nitrogen at a flow rate of 50 mL/min for 3 min. The oxidation and reduction processes were purged with argon at a 50 mL/min flow rate for 2 min in between to prevent mixing oxygen and ethane. During the ethane ODH stage, we injected 10 % ethane/ balanced nitrogen into the U-tube reactor at a 30 mL/min flow rate via an Alice mass flow controller for a continuous reaction of 2 min. We used a gas vacuum bag to collect all gases for compositional analysis by a GC-2014. Before collection, the aluminum foil gas bag was purged with inert gas for several minutes to remove all air and potential contaminants. Immediately after collection, the bag is sealed to prevent gas leakage and contaminant interference. The collected foil gas bag was connected to the inlet port of the Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatograph, and the tail gas was manually injected into the column. Hydrocarbons were analyzed by a flame ionization detector (FID), and CO/CO2 and H2 were analyzed by two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD). The catalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated in the C2H6 conversion, the selectivity of C2H4, CH4, CO, and CO2, the C2H4 yield, and H2 conversion with the following formula. All measurements were made using molar amounts of substances. In this experiment, carbon balances were all between 95 ± 5 %. More detailed calculations and formulas can be found in Part S2.3. Conversion of C 2 H 6 ( % ) = C 2 H 6 introduced − C 2 H 6 residual C 2 H 6 introduced × 100 % Selectivity of C 2 H 4 ( % ) = C 2 H 4 produced C 2 H 6 converted × 100 % After selecting the optimal reaction temperature and oxygen carrier, the reaction temperature was fixed, and different space velocities (GHSV 900 h−1∼3600 h−1) were used to study the effect of gas space velocity on the reaction performance. The experimental steps were the same as those described above. 2.4 Characterization of redox catalysts Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP-OES, KTYT-799) was used to determine the actual content of element Mn in the samples. About 0.2 g of the sample was weighed, 20 mL of HCl was added and stirred for 5 h to dissolve the Mn element, followed by filtration, and finally, the solution was calibrated to 50 mL for the ICP test. The samples' crystal structures were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, X’Pert3 Powder-DY5103). Cu Kɑ radiation (λ = 0.15406 Å) was used as the excitation source, the target voltage was 40 kV, the target current was 40 mA, and the diffraction angle was scanned from 15° to 80° in 15°/min increments. The elemental composition and chemical states were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha). Al Kα rays (hv=1486.6 eV) were used as the excitation source with a spot size of 400 μm, an operating voltage of 12 kV, a filament current of 6 mA, and C1s (284.8 eV) as the reference peak to calibrate the binding energies of other elements in the spectrum. A scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU-5000) was used to observe the surface morphology of the samples, which had an accelerating voltage of 3 kV and a working distance of 5 mm. Surface elements were also analyzed using Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, XFlash6110). It is worth noting that in the SEM test, the samples need to be gold sprayed before observation. The particle size distribution of catalyst active species was observed based on the Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM, Ultim Max 80). JW-TB440A Specific Surface Area and Pore Size Analyzer can get the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. The specific surface area is calculated using Brunauer Emmett Tell (BET) theory, and pore size is estimated using the Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) or Saito-Foley (SF) methods. Before testing, the samples were pretreated at 300 ℃ under vacuum for 1 h. Determination of the intensity and number of acidic sites on the catalyst surface utilizing temperature-controlled desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD, Builder Electronic PCA-1200). A sample of about 0.2 g was weighed and loaded into a quartz reactor, pretreated in a stream of highly purified N2 at 200 ℃ for 1 h, cooled to 100 ℃, and then subjected to ammonia adsorption at a gas flow of 1 % NH3/balance N2 for 1 h, and then purged with highly purified N2 for 30 min at 100 ℃. The equipment was used to record the data from 80 to 1000 ℃ in a highly purified He flow environment at an elevated temperature rate of 10 ℃/min. The data were recorded from 80 to 1000 ℃ at a ramp rate of 10 ℃/min in a highly purified He stream. Oxygen storage properties (nucleated and adsorbed oxygen) of the catalyst were investigated using temperature-controlled desorption of O2 (O2-TPD, apparatus as above). A typical sample of about 0.2 g was taken and pretreated in high-purity N2 at 125 °C for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was treated in a 10 % O2/balance N2 stream at 60 °C for 30 min and then heated from 50 °C to 900 °C in a He gas stream at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and the signals were recorded with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR, apparatus as above) was used to determine the type of active species of the samples. The metal ions and the O on the zeolite formed the oxide structure, which was characterized according to the specific reduction temperature that the metal oxides have. A 0.05 g sample was pretreated in a stream of highly purified N2 at 125 ℃ for 1 h, chilled to less than 50 ℃, and then heated to 900 ℃ at 10 % H2/90 % Ar at a rate of 10 ℃/min. The gas flow rates mentioned above were all 30 mL/min. Fourier transform infrared (Py-IR, Bruker Tensor 27) of pyridine adsorption was used to identify the type of acidic site (Brønsted acid site or Lewis acid site). A powder sample of about 20 mg was prepared as a self-supporting sheet (13 mm (ID)) and fixed in the IR cell; the sample was placed in the in-situ cell programmed to be warmed up to 350 °C and pretreated under vacuum for 1 h, cooled down to room temperature, and the spectrum was scanned as a background. After adsorption of pyridine at room temperature, the programmed temperature was raised to the determination temperature (fixed point temperatures of 150 °C, 200 °C and 350 °C, respectively) for vacuum desorption and then cooled to room temperature, respectively, to record the infrared spectral data in the wavelength region of 1400–1600 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology of redox catalysts Observations of the surface morphology from the SEM images of the samples revealed that the untreated HY zeolite exhibited a typical hexagonal prism structure with a smooth surface and uniform particle size distribution. After loading with Mn active species, there were no significant changes in the appearance and morphology of the catalyst, as seen in Figs. 1(a) to 1(e). Further, the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of 3Mn/HY, shown in Fig. 1(f), revealed an interlayer spacing of about 0.16 nm, demonstrating the fine structural features of the catalyst. ICP-OES (Table S2) analysis confirmed that the actual loading of Mn in the xMn / HY catalyst was roughly equivalent to the theoretical value. In the graphical data presented ( Fig. 2), the XRD spectrum of the HY zeolite carrier conforms to the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) card (PDF #39–1830), exhibited a pronounced FAU (faujasite) topological structure, indicative of high crystallinity. Compared to the original HY carrier, the xMn / HY catalyst retains the FAU structure after adding Mn. However, its characteristic diffraction peaks at 6.22°, 15.74°, and 23.68°, corresponding to the crystal planes (111), (331), and (533), respectively, are significantly weaker. This attenuation likely stems from the introduction of Mn ions, which appears to disrupt the ordered structure of the HY carrier, resulting in a decrement in crystallinity [8]. Diffraction peaks corresponding to the Mn2O3 phase (PDF #24–0508) were identified within the xMn / HY samples, with no additional diffraction peaks for Mn or MnOx phases detected. This result suggests highly dispersed manganese oxides were formed on the HY zeolites, predominantly Mn2O3. Such a uniform distribution of the active component on the carrier enhances the effective collision rate between the reactant gases and the active sites, facilitating the catalytic reaction process. The N2 adsorption-desorption experiments ( Fig. 3(a)) showed that the untreated HY zeolite and the Mn-loaded HY catalyst exhibited Type I isotherm characteristics, indicating a predominantly microporous structure. The pore size distribution data (Fig. 3(b)) further revealed that the pores of the samples were mainly concentrated around 0.60 nm. Specifically, the unmodified HY carrier had a specific surface area of 523.46 m2/g, a total pore volume of 0.40 cm3/g, and an average pore diameter of 0.56 nm ( Table 1）, while the addition of Mn significantly changed these parameters. Notably, with the increase in Mn loading, there was a trend of increasing specific surface area, which might be due to the high dispersion of Mn active species on the catalyst surface, exposing more active sites and thus enhancing the catalyst activity. The slight decrease in pore volume might be due to the incorporation of Mn species leading to the blockage of some pores [22], which is consistent with the XRD analysis results and further proves the successful loading of Mn active species and their impact on the pore structure of the HY zeolite. Overall, these results demonstrate the successful preparation of the xMn / HY catalyst and reveal its excellent structure characteristics and potential for catalytic activity. 3.2 Performance analysis and stability testing of catalysts To investigate the feasibility of Mn-loaded HY carriers for the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction of ethane, catalysts with different Mn-loading amounts as active substances were prepared for the comparative experiments of oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and the reaction influencing factors were continuously varied to obtain the optimal reaction conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4(a) examines the effect of inert carrier versus oxide additive changes in ethane CL-ODH. It can be seen that the ethane conversion process produces more carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide (COx) and carbon deposits when 3Co / HY and 3Cu / HY catalysts are used, when the ethylene selectivity is 61.64 % and 59.66 %, respectively. For cobalt-based catalysts, the optimum reaction temperature is 300–650 °C. Excessively high temperatures (e.g., 700 °C) may lead to the formation of carbon deposits. On the other hand, the higher activity of Cu oxides may be associated with causing over-oxidation of ethane, generating COx and coke [23–25]. Although Fe and Mn have similar electronic properties, they behave differently regarding catalytic properties. For the 3Fe / HY sample, the ethylene selectivity can reach 89.94 %, but there is still apparent coke generation, which may be due to the relatively poor dispersion of the Fe catalyst surface [26]. We also investigated the performance of Mn-based redox catalysts prepared by loading manganese into other metal oxides such as Al2O3 and Fe2O3. It can be observed that when Al2O3 or Fe2O3 were used as oxygen carriers, the ethylene selectivity was not high, and there was severe carbon accumulation. ZSM-5 zeolite is not as effective as HY zeolite, although it has higher ethylene selectivity, such difference may be caused by different pore structures and silica-aluminum ratio, HY zeolite ratio usually has a lower silica-aluminum ratio, between about 2.5–6, which means that it has higher aluminum content and stronger acidity [27]. The results of the ethane oxidative dehydrogenation reaction performance with different Mn loadings are shown in Fig. 4(b). It is noted that the ethylene selectivity of the samples is gradually increasing, accompanied by the decrease of ethane conversion with the increase of Mn elemental content. It is reasonable to speculate that introducing a moderate content of Mn is beneficial to improve the acid catalytic activity of the zeolite, thus enhancing the catalytic performance of the samples. The details need to be analyzed in conjunction with the subsequent characterization. Moreover, the catalytic efficiency is greatly influenced by the redox characteristics of the catalyst as well as the interactions between the manganese species and the zeolite support. These aspects require further analysis in conjunction with subsequent characterization data. Fig. 4(c) demonstrates the effect of different gas space-time velocities (GHSV) on the reaction performance. When the GHSV was set to 900 h−1, ethane had a longer residence time on the catalyst surface, contributing to ethane conversion. However, the excessively long residence time might lead to the further reaction of some of the generated ethylene to form other olefins, which slightly reduces the selectivity of ethylene. When the GHSV was increased to 1800 h−1, the residence time was reduced, which may reduce the chance of over-reaction of ethylene, improving ethylene selectivity to 97.14 %. When the GHSV was further increased to 3600 h−1, although the conversion of ethane was significantly increased, the partially converted ethylene might not have enough time to detach from the catalyst surface due to the residence time becoming very short, which in turn continued the reaction to generate by-products, resulting in a decrease in the selectivity of ethylene to 88.86 %. Therefore, we explored 1800 h−1 as the optimum GHSV for 3Mn / HY in ethane CL-ODH. Fig. 4(d) shows the effect of reaction temperature on the ODH performance of 3Mn / HY. It can be found that the ethane conversion gradually increased from 12 % to 34 % as the temperature was increased from 675 °C to 725 °C, but carbon deposition started to occur at 725 °C, which might be related to the depletion of lattice oxygen in the redox catalyst [28–30]. At elevated temperatures, the reaction rate increases without a corresponding increase in the regeneration rate of lattice oxygen, leading to an insufficient oxygen supply for the ODH reactions, which in turn affects the complete oxidation of the carbon intermediates. More detailed reaction test outcomes for the various redox catalysts are shown in Table S3. In conclusion, after performance testing, the 3Mn / HY catalysts with excellent pore structural properties and catalytic activity potential did exhibit excellent performance under specific conditions, reaching about 97.1 % ethylene selectivity and 22.7 % ethane conversion, making it an ideal candidate for the ethane CL-ODH reaction. 3.3 Redox activity of the samples In a previous performance exploration (Fig. 4(a)), we revealed a family of redox catalysts consisting of metal-modified HY zeolites (3X / HY, X = Fe, Co, Cu, Mn), which exhibited significant variability in catalytic performance. Of these, the 3Mn / HY catalysts stood out for their remarkable catalytic selectivity (more than 97.1 %), strongly suggesting that introducing manganese oxides could be the decisive factor. Therefore, we did the following characterization aiming to deeply explore how redox properties affect the activity and selectivity of the catalogs. From the H2-TPR analysis ( Fig. 5(a)), it is observed that varying Mn-loading contents result in different reduction behaviors. The 3Mn / HY sample exhibits a distinct reduction peak between 400 and 700 °C, which can be deconvoluted into three separated peaks at different positions corresponding to three different reduction stages. These peaks can be attributed to the successive reduction of MnO2 → Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 → MnO [31]. In contrast, the reduction profiles for the samples with 1 wt% Mn (1Mn / HY) and 2 wt% Mn (2Mn / HY) on HY are smoother, suggesting that the Mn predominantly exists in lower oxidation states, thereby requiring lower temperatures for reduction and resulting in more gradual reaction profiles [32]. Further evidence for this may be found in Table S4, where the hydrogen consumption of the 1Mn / HY and 2Mn / HY catalysts was 0.01 mmol·g−1 and 0.02 mmol·g−1, respectively. These values were much less than the 3.78 mmol·g−1 hydrogen consumption of the 3Mn / HY catalyst. The higher amount of hydrogen consumed means that more metal ions are reduced and the initial oxidation state is higher [33]. From this, it can be inferred that the highest average oxidation state of manganese was found in the 3Mn / HY, while the lowest average oxidation state was found in the 1Mn / HY catalyst. Furthermore, the reduction peak is shifted towards higher temperatures with increasing Mn content, implying that the Mn oxides interact more strongly with the HY zeolites [34]. This is also confirmed in Fig. S1. From the Mn 2p orbitals of the XPS spectrum of the Mn2O3 catalyst, the peak binding energy is 641.8 eV, corresponding to Mn3+, indicating the presence of Mn2O3. The binding energy of Mn in the xMn / HY (x = 1, 2, 3) catalyst is shifted to a higher value after loading Mn2O3. The magnitude of the binding energy shift is 3Mn / HY (1.4 eV) > 2Mn / HY (0.8 eV) > 1Mn / HY (0.6 eV). We speculate that the interaction between Mn metal oxides and HY carriers is stronger in 3Mn / HY [35]. The higher interaction strength contributes to the formation of specific active sites that may be more inclined to promote the pathway of ethane conversion to ethylene rather than the deep oxidation of ethylene into carbon dioxide or other by-products [36,37], thus endowing the 3Mn / HY redox catalysts with higher selectivity. In the O2-TPD analysis (Fig. 5(b)), four distinct desorption curves correspond to the series of HY molecular sieve samples with varying Mn loadings (HY, 1Mn / HY, 2Mn / HY, 3Mn / HY). For the HY sample devoid of Mn loading, the oxygen desorption peaks were mainly distributed in the 100 ℃ - 600 ℃ interval; in addition, there were also significant signals near 700 ℃ and 800 ℃. It was reported that these peaks are associated with various types of surface-adsorbed oxygen species (e.g., O2 -, O2 2-, O-), surface lattice oxygen, and bulk phase lattice oxygen [38,39]. As Mn loading increased, the high-temperature detachment peaks (near 700 °C and 800 °C) gradually weakened. Meanwhile, the medium-temperature detachment peaks (located between approximately 300 °C and 500 °C) not only increased in intensity but also appeared to migrate to lower temperatures, indicating that the addition of Mn effectively reduced the content of high-temperature lattice oxygen, and at the same time promoted the generation of medium-temperature surface adsorbed oxygen. Through integral fitting the O2-TPD curve, we calculated the ratio of the surface adsorbed oxygen peak area to the total area of the catalyst. The results showed that the ratio was in the following order from high to low: 2MnHY (99.33 %) > 1MnHY (98.96 %) > 3MnHY (93.66 %) > HY (82.45 %). See Table S5 for more information. However, in conjunction with the performance of Fig. 4(b), although the 2Mn / HY sample possessed the highest ratio of adsorbed oxygen on the surface, this did not mean that it had the best catalytic performance. This finding suggests a moderate amount of surface-adsorbed oxygen is necessary to maintain sufficient active sites. Still, an excessive amount of surface-adsorbed oxygen may lead to catalyst deactivation. In contrast, the 3Mn / HY sample showed optimal performance in the catalytic reaction due to the optimal ratio of surface-adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen. XPS analysis further revealed the mechanism behind this phenomenon. The O 1 s spectra ( Fig. 6(a)), spanning the binding energy from 538.00 to 527.00 eV, were decomposed into three types of oxygen species: OI (lattice oxygen, O2-), OII (surface adsorbed oxygen), and OIII (hydroxyl / carbonate-like oxygen species, e.g., OH-/CO3 2-) [40,41], all pivotal for the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction. As shown in Table 2, it can be seen that surface-adsorbed oxygen（OⅡ） dominates the oxygen species of the HY zeolite and xMn / HY redox catalysts. The HY catalyst possessed 51.96 % of surface-adsorbed oxygen, which gradually increased to 73.24 % with the addition of manganese. It seemed that the introduction of manganese changed the oxygen environment on the catalyst surface and promoted the formation or stabilization of surface-adsorbed oxygen, which resulted in more oxygen atoms in a highly active surface-adsorbed state [42,43], which are more easily involved in the catalytic cycle. Detailed information on the specific types of oxygen species and their content distribution is provided in Table S6 in the Supporting Information. O2-TPD and XPS consistently showed that manganese doping significantly increased the number of oxygen species and their easily desorbed species at low and medium temperatures. Compared with the oxygen embedded in the lattice, these adsorbed oxygen species, which are directly exposed to the catalyst surface, become selective oxygen carriers in the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction due to their ability to be in more direct contact with the reactants and thus more susceptible to electron transfer [44], which plays a positive role in improving the selectivity of the product ethylene. Detailed quantitative XPS analysis of the Mn 2p3/2 orbital with varying Mn loadings (Fig. 6(b)) revealed characteristic peak positions for Mn2+ (at 641.70 eV), Mn3+ (642.43 eV), and Mn4+ (644.42 eV) [45–47], each representing different oxidation states of manganese. The compiled data indicates the proportion of Mn3+ among total manganese ions. As manganese was incorporated into the HY zeolites, the percentage of Mn3+ / (Mn4+ + Mn3+ + Mn2+) increased from 41.51 % to 44.82 %. The 3Mn / HY catalysts exhibited higher levels of Mn3+, which is regarded as a trait likely crucial for their demonstrated excellent selectivity [48,49]. Theoretically, lower-valent manganese (Mn2+) might result in diminished catalytic activity, whereas higher-valent states (Mn4+ and Mn3+), with enhanced oxidation capabilities, are favorable for the conversion of ethane to ethylene and water. However, excessive oxidation potential might lead to the over-oxidization of ethylene, thereby reducing selectivity. Therefore, a moderate oxidation state, such as Mn3+, effectively prevents side reactions and boosts the selective production efficiency of ethylene while maintaining catalyst activity. Additional XPS details about the xMn / HY catalysts can be found in Table S7. 3.4 Effect of acid sites on the performance of redox catalysts In this study, the effect of Mn metal oxides on the acidic character of HY zeolites was explored in depth by NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. 7(a), NH3-TPD analysis revealed that HY zeolites without Mn loading predominantly displayed NH3 desorption peaks near 217 °C, 315 °C, and 426 °C, corresponding to weak, medium, and strong acid centers, respectively. The NH3 desorption peaks for 1Mn / HY samples shifted toward the mid-temperature range, suggesting that Mn addition optimized the distribution of acid centers, particularly by promoting the formation of weak and medium-strong acid sites. This modification favors the breaking of the C-H bond [50], which enhances catalyst selectivity and reduces the risk of carbon deposition of the redox catalyst. We employed Py-IR to identify the type of acid center further. In the experiments, pyridine molecules interact with Lewis acid sites (LAS) within the HY zeolite to form complexes (LPy) and with Brønsted acid sites (BAS) to form pyridinium ions (PyH+), altering the original absorption peaks of pyridine. The resulting pyridinium complexes and ions exhibit characteristic infrared spectral bands [51,52]. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the 1539 cm−1 and 1445 cm−1 peaks in the HY samples indicate Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [53]. With increasing Mn content, the absorption peaks corresponding to Brønsted acid sites weakened, whereas those of Lewis acid sites intensified. This trend implies that the addition of Mn induced a shift from the original Si-O(H)-Al structure to the Si(Al)-O-Mn structure, which led to an overall decrease in the B/L ratio [54], accompanied by a reduction in the number of Brønsted acid sites and an increase in the number of Lewis acid sites. In light of the performance results, this adjustment is favorable for catalytic oxidation reactions. The detailed acidic properties are further outlined in the accompanying Table S8. Comprehensive analyses of NH3-TPD and Py-IR revealed that the introduction of Mn metal oxides on HY zeolites optimized the distribution of acid centers and significantly enhanced the performance of the catalysts by increasing the number of Lewis acid sites. Particularly importantly, the Lewis acidity enhancement helped to achieve highly selective catalytic oxidation reactions. In olefins, π-bonded electron pairs not involved in σ-bond formation can be coordinated to the empty orbitals in the Lewis acid center, an action that significantly activates the substrate molecule. This coordination enhances the charge transfer from the metal catalyst center to the Lewis acid-activated substrate, effectively reducing the activation energy in the catalytic cycle and thus accelerating the reaction rate. In addition, Lewis acid can significantly enhance reaction selectivity by finely tuning the stability of the reaction intermediates [55–58]. We effectively generated 3Mn / S-1 catalysts by loading 3 % weight percent Mn into Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite; the ICP findings (Table S2) confirm this. Through a comparison analysis with the 3Mn / HY catalyst, we investigate the variations in performance between them. According to the XPS results of 3Mn / S-1 (Fig. S2), Mn mainly exists in the catalyst in the form of Mn3+, as shown by the peak position at 642.19 eV in the XPS spectrum. This result is consistent with the distribution state of Mn oxygen species on the 3Mn / HY catalyst. Therefore, the critical difference between the two was the presence of acidic sites within the HY zeolite. In contrast, the S-1 zeolite did not naturally possess acidic sites due to its all-silica structure, and the introduction of manganese did not induce additional acidity. This was confirmed in the NH3-TPD analysis, as shown in Fig. 8(a). The performance of the 3Mn / S-1 catalyst was tested at 700 °C and 1800 mL·h−1·g−1GHSV in a fixed-bed reactor. As revealed in Fig. 8(b), the selectivity of this catalyst for ethylene was only 89.1 %, and ethane conversion was 12.8 % under carbon equilibrium conditions. In contrast, the 3Mn / HY catalyst achieved a better balance between redox activity and selectivity thanks to the synergistic effect between the Lewis acid center therein and the Mn oxides, which, as the active component, could promote the migration of oxygen atoms more efficiently and reduce the activation energy of the catalytic cycle, thus accelerating the catalytic reaction rate with the assistance of the Lewis acid center. This synergistic mechanism promotes the regioselective functionalization of the C-H bond [56], resulting in the 3Mn / HY catalyst exhibiting excellent activity and ethylene selectivity in the ethane oxidative dehydrogenation reaction, which significantly exceeds that of the 3Mn / S-1 catalyst with no acidic sites. Under the same operating conditions, the 3Mn / HY catalyst not only improved the conversion but also significantly enhanced the ethylene selectivity. 3.5 Stability testing of catalysts To test the stability of the samples, we chose the 3Mn / HY sample to undergo cyclic reaction at 700 °C, 1800 mL·h −1·g−1GHSV; the results are shown in Fig. 9, and the raw data are shown in Table S9. It can be seen that the ethylene selectivity of the sample could be maintained at about 97.1 % after 20 successive reactions. However, with an increase in the number of cycles, the COx content increased and was accompanied by a gradual decline in catalytic performance. Through analysis of the SEM images (Fig. S3) of the post-reaction HY and xMn / HY redox catalysts, it is revealed that substantial agglomeration and gradual accumulation of carbon deposition occurred on the catalyst surface over the successive cyclic test. This carbon deposition, likely caused by C-H bond cleavage or other side reactions, covered the active sites of the catalyst, hindering effective contact with reactants. In addition, the XRD patterns (Fig. S4) indicated that the crystalline structure of the 3Mn / HY redox catalysts remained unchanged before and after cycling, indicating that the sample kept in the form of Mn2O3, and no other Mn metal oxides were found to be generated. However, measuring the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the 3Mn / HY catalysts before and after cycling found that the specific surface area and pore volume of the samples decreased after cycling (Table S10). This suggests that the unique pore structure of the HY zeolite was partially damaged during continuous high-temperature reactions [59], which might also contribute to the decline in catalytic activity. More importantly, compared to the fresh sample, the post-cyclic redox 3Mn / HY sample showed a significant reduction of the acid content based on the NH3-TPD test (Fig. S5), which is believed to affect its ODH reactivity further. By comparing the XPS analysis results of catalysts before and after the redox reaction, it can be found that the distribution and nature of the O and Mn species have undergone significant changes. Specifically, the changes in the O 1 s region are shown in Fig. S6(a), which shows that the intensity of the lattice oxygen (OI) peaks and the surface adsorbed oxygen (OII) peaks weakened. In contrast, the intensity of the hydroxyl/carbon-oxygen (OIII) peaks strengthened during the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane. This implies a continuous decrease in surface oxygen in the reaction, increasing oxygen vacancies in the oxygen-carrying body, which contributes to a constant migration of lattice oxygen from the bulk phase to the surface [60,61]. In addition, the observation of the Mn 2p3/2 region showed an increase in the intensity of the characteristic peaks of Mn4+ in the 3Mn / HY catalysts after use (Fig. S6(b)). This change implies that there may be re-oxidation of Mn3+ to Mn4+ during the catalytic reaction, possibly due to the reduction of surface oxygen. An increase in Mn4+ Usually leads to a decrease in the number of active centers on the catalyst, which may cause catalyst deactivation. More detailed XPS data before and after the reaction are shown in Tables S8 and S9. 4 Conclusion This study successfully doped Mn metal oxides into HY molecular sieves by isovolumetric impregnation to create a series of xMn / HY (x = 1, 2, 3) oxygen carriers. Among them, 3Mn / HY exhibited excellent catalytic activity and cyclic stability in the catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (CL-ODH). H2-TPR analysis showed significant reduction peaks in the 400–700 °C range, indicating solid interactions between Mn and HY. O2-TPD and XPS results indicated that 3Mn / HY was enriched with easily desorbed surface adsorbed oxygen and a higher proportion of Mn3+, improving catalytic activity and ethylene selectivity. NH3-TPD and Py-IR analyses revealed that Mn optimized acid center distribution and increased Lewis acid sites, enhancing catalyst performance. These findings highlight the crucial synergistic interaction between Mn ions and Lewis acid centers for efficient ethane oxidative dehydrogenation, guiding the development of new efficient and highly selective redox catalysts. coredata.dc:description: As the crucial role of zeolite catalysts becomes increasingly prominent in refining and petrochemical industries, this study introduces a novel application of xMn / HY catalysts in ethane catalytic dehydrogenation via Chemical Looping Oxidative Dehydrogenation (CL-ODH). The synergistic effect of manganese oxides on the HY framework and a moderate amount of acidic sites within the catalyst facilitates the cleavage of C-H bonds and the desorption of olefins, which are vital for advancing ethane CL-ODH. We identified the reasons for maintaining high ethylene selectivity using advanced characterization techniques such as XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR. Notably, under optimized conditions at 700 °C with a gas time-space velocity (GHSV) of 1800 mL·h−1·g−1, the 3Mn/HY catalyst achieved approximately 97.1 % selectivity for ethylene and a 22.7 % conversion of ethane. These findings present a scalable route for ethylene production, showcasing significant industrial relevance by potentially reducing energy costs and improving yield.
